page.title: 03Villages - Tamar Valley.
page.content: The villages in our area were not on a map drawn in 1865. They owe their existance to the working of the copper mines of the late 1800's. Gunnislake, was built because of the Devon Great Consols mine on the other side of the river, where the land was owned by the Duke of Bedford. He did not want to lose his pheasant coverts, so he would not allow houses to be built on his land. So the miners had to build a village, which was called Gunnislake, on the Cornish side of the river (a gunnis is a worked-out part of a mine). Drakewalls, St. Ann's Chapel and Albaston really form one large village built around old mines. Higher and Lower Metherell, once only scattered farms, are now two small villages. In all the villages, as well as old cottages, there are now many modern bungalows.
